mainText:
With $1,000 given to the council by the Western-backed Syrian national coalition, they fixed damaged converters to restore electricity, needed to power the well in the town.
A brigade from the town of Al Bab had recently seized control of the hydroelectric generators at the Tishreen Dam but initially refused to share the power.
They then set out to negotiate for electricity.
But the young civilians quickly shouldered their mandate.
How did they know that the council was not a pack of thieves, the brigade demanded?
shownText:
“If you bring them 10 prophets from God they will still keep complaining!”
Mr. Khatib said of Tilalyan’s young council.

With $1,000 given to the council by the Western-backed Syrian national coalition, they fixed damaged converters to restore electricity, needed to power the well in the town.
A brigade from the town of Al Bab had recently seized control of the hydroelectric generators at the Tishreen Dam but initially refused to share the power.
They then set out to negotiate for electricity.
But the young civilians quickly shouldered their mandate.
How did they know that the council was not a pack of thieves, the brigade demanded?

Then the larger neighboring town of Tal Rifaat was hogging all the electricity, refusing to allow any to pass through to Tilalyan or Marea, Mr. Moussa said.
But when it came to electricity, Marea’s powerful brigade and civilian leaders stepped in to help; Marea and Tilalyan are on the same power line.
title: Syrian Civilians Take Reins in Test of Self-Government - NYTimes.com
